Grass-types: Grass-types such as Rillaboom, Tapu Bulu, and Mega Venusaur can pose huge threats to Rotom-W, as they resist both of its STAB moves and threaten it back with their STAB moves. However, physical Grass-types don't appreciate being burned by Will-O-Wisp on the switch.

Dragon-types: Dragon-types such as Mega Altaria, Kommo-o, and Hydreigon can easily threaten Rotom-W, as they also resist both of its STAB moves and can set up on it with ease. Mega Altaria can also circumvent status moves like Will-O-Wisp due to Refresh, which allows it to easily set up with Dragon Dance.

Specially Defensive Walls: Specially defensive walls such as Blissey, Celebi, and Alolan Muk can tank numerous hits from Rotom-W and threaten it with their moves, forcing it out as a result.

Stallbreakers: Stallbreakers such as Bulk Up Zarude and Kommo-o are large threats to Rotom-W, as they can take both of its STAB moves with ease and freely set up on it without worrying about status moves due to Taunt.

Residual Damage: Residual damage such as burn, Toxic, and Stealth Rock can take advantage of Rotom-W's lack of reliable recovery, which negatively impacts its longevity during a match. Burn notably cancels out Rotom-W's Leftovers recovery.

Mold Breaker Excadrill: Excadrill's access to Mold Breaker lets it ignore Levitate and completely break through Rotom-W with Earthquake. However, it's unable to come in on a Hydro Pump or Will-O-Wisp. However, physically defensive variants of Rotom-W can live an Earthquake from Excadrill at full health and KO it with Hydro Pump.

Gastrodon and Seismitoad: Gastrodon and Seismitoad can easily switch in on Rotom-W's Hydro Pump due to their access to Storm Drain and Water Absorb, respectively, while blocking its Volt Switch due to their Ground typing. Gastrodon can then cripple Rotom-W with Toxic, while Seismitoad can weaken Rotom-W with Grass Knot. However, both are put on a timer by Toxic if Rotom-W is running it, which limits their ability to switch in freely.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot (Electric)
sets.description:
Rotom-W is a great defensive pivot for Electric teams thanks to its good bulk, Water typing, and Levitate, which combine to let it handle threats like Sand Rush Excadrill, Mamoswine, and Gliscor while threatening them with a powerful STAB Hydro Pump. Additionally, its Water typing means it can check Fire- and Water-types such as Blacephalon, Victini, and Urshifu-R that are otherwise difficult to deal with for Electric teams. Volt Switch can bring in offensive teammates like Tapu Koko, Regieleki, and Zeraora safely in a match. It also works very well in tandem with Hydro Pump, as Rotom-W can pressure numerous Ground-types and prevent them from blocking Volt Switch. Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers like Mega Gallade, Weavile, and Garchomp, and it is especially effective against switch-ins like Tapu Bulu and Rillaboom. Pain Split is helpful if Rotom-W is weakened, healing off of high-HP foes such as Blissey. Alternatively, Defog may be used to let Rotom-W act as an entry hazard remover on teams should Zapdos lack Defog. Leftovers gives Rotom-W a form of recovery outside of Pain Split, making it weakened less easily. 44 Speed EVs are used in order to outspeed Jolly Azumarill, while 252 HP and 212 Special Defense EVs along with a Calm nature make Rotom-W more effective against special attackers such as Blacephalon, Greninja, and Choice Specs Pelipper.

All teammates benefit from Rotom-W's typing allowing it to notably check Ground-, Fire-, and Water-types such as Sand Rush Excadrill, Mamoswine, Blacephalon, and Urshifu-R, as Electric teams otherwise have limited defensive checks to these Pokemon. Zapdos forms an excellent defensive core with Rotom-W, as Zapdos can deal with Grass-types that give Rotom-W trouble such as Tapu Bulu, Rillaboom, and Ferrothorn. Additionally, Zapdos can take on Mold Breaker Excadrill, which is very problematic for Rotom-W and the rest of Electric teams. Choice Specs Zapdos can also be used to break through additional Grass-types like Mega Venusaur and Cradily with a powerful STAB Hurricane. Tapu Koko and Play Rough Zeraora can deal with numerous Dragon-types that Rotom-W heavily struggles against such as Kommo-o, Mega Latias, and Hydreigon. Additionally, Tapu Koko can pressure troublesome Ground-types for Rotom-W like Gastrodon, Seismitoad, and Swampert with Grass Knot. Zeraora pressures specially defensive walls such as Blissey and Galarian Slowking for Rotom-W. Alolan Raichu can take on threats like Mega Venusaur due to its Psychic typing while utilizing Grass Knot in order to defeat Ground-types that give Rotom-W trouble, such as Gastrodon, Seismitoad, and Swampert. Regieleki appreciates Rotom-W's ability to eliminate most Ground-types with Hydro Pump, giving it a great opportunity to break through the opposing team with its powerful Electric-type moves. Alolan Golem and Magnezone can trap and eliminate Steel-types such as Mold Breaker Excadrill and Ferrothorn, with both often being immune to Excadrill's Earthquake due to Air Balloon.

Excadrill.comments:
Other Options

Steel

Leftovers or Focus Sash may be used on Swords Dance Excadrill to improve its longevity and or better ensure at least one KO, but both lower its ability to threaten Flying-types.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Steel)
sets.description:
Excadrill is Steel's go-to revenge killer with its excellent Ground- and Rock-type coverage, which makes it a solid wincon against Fire, Electric, and Poison teams. Earthquake works well with Excadrill's ability, Mold Breaker, allowing it to threaten Rotom-W and Galarian Weezing. Rock Blast may be used over Rock Slide to get past Substitutes from Kyurem and Dragonite's Multiscale, but the damage is highly inconsistent. Toxic allows Excadrill to put Mega Sableye, a huge roadblock for Steel teams, on a timer due to Mold Breaker, in addition to punishing common switch-ins such as Landorus-T, Slowbro, and Porygon2. Rapid Spin removes entry hazards without clearing the hazards Steel teams stack. A Choice Scarf with a Jolly nature lets Excadrill outspeed threats such as unboosted Volcarona, Victini, and Zeraora and boosted Kommo-o.

Ferrothorn provides Excadrill with a switch-in to Water-types like Mega Swampert and Slowbro, and it helps Excadrill break through defensive cores with Stealth Rock and Spikes support. Corviknight, Skarmory, or Celesteela provides Excadrill with a Ground immunity. Corviknight can give it a safe switch-in with U-turn and threaten Fighting-types with Brave Bird, Skarmory can set entry hazards so that Excadrill can force progress against bulkier teams, and Celesteela threatens Grass-types like Ferrothorn, Rillaboom, and Zarude with Flamethrower. In return, Excadrill provides an Electric immunity and can take on threats such as Choice Band Zeraora and Tapu Koko. Aegislash and Heatran provide a Fighting and Fire immunity, respectively, and can switch into most special attacks aimed at Excadrill. Heatran, in particular, can nullify V-create from Choice Scarf Victini, which outspeeds Excadrill and poses a huge threat to Steel teams. Wallbreakers such as Bisharp, Mega Scizor, and Choice Specs Aegislash can pressure physical walls such as Porygon2, Slowbro, and Mega Venusaur, which helps Excadrill clean opposing Normal, Psychic, and Poison teams late-game.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Steel)
sets.description:
With Swords Dance, Excadrill becomes a threatening sweeper and late-game cleaner, as it can break through bulky Pokemon such as Toxapex, Melmetal, and Mandibuzz. Rock Slide deals with Flying-types that switch into Excadrill such as Crobat, Zapdos, and Mega Charizard Y. Rapid Spin boosts Excadrill's Speed, letting it take advantage of forced switches and outspeed checks such as Gengar, Zeraora, and Mega Charizard Y. Rockium Z allows Excadrill to bypass checks in Celesteela and Mandibuzz, as well as ensuring the OHKO on both Mega Charizard X and Mega Charizard Y.

Ferrothorn can take on Water- and Ground-type moves from Urshifu-R and Mega Swampert aimed at Excadrill, and it also sets entry hazards to help Excadrill break down the opposing team. Aegislash provides a Fighting immunity and can weaken checks such as Slowbro and Mantine with Toxic. Heatran provides a Fire immunity and can check threats like Victini and Volcarona, which Swords Dance Excadrill cannot due to not running Choice Scarf. Corviknight and Skarmory provide a Ground immunity and can check Fighting-types such as Terrakion. Alternatively, Celesteela may be used as the Ground-immune partner, as it can handle offensive threats such as Rillaboom and Mega Diancie that Excadrill struggles with. These Ground-immune teammates also lure in Electric-types such as Tapu Koko and Magnezone, which Excadrill can set up on. Choice Scarf Magnezone forms a good wallbreaking core with Excadrill, as it removes Steel-types like Skarmory and Ferrothorn that Excadrill struggles with, as well as removing threats like Keldeo and Urshifu-R. Jirachi and Mega Scizor benefit from Excadrill's wallbreaking abilities, as they can clean late-game against Poison and Flying teams and Dragon and Fighting teams, respectively.

Darmanitan-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Ice

Galarian Darmanitan has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Ice

Physically Defensive Walls: While Galarian Darmanitan has amazing damage output, it struggles to get past extremely bulky physical walls such as Galarian Corsola, Mega Slowbro, and Porygon2, especially if it's running Choice Scarf. As a result, they are able to wear it down with their status or attacking moves. However, Choice Band variants of Galarian Darmanitan can 2HKO these walls.

Rotom-W: Rotom-W is an extremely effective check to Galarian Darmanitan; it resists both Icicle Crash and Flare Blitz, is immune to Earthquake due to Levitate, and threatens to wear it down with Hydro Pump or cripple it with Will-O-Wisp.

Status: Burn greatly hinders Galarian Darmanitan's wallbreaking. Paralysis leaves it more easily revenge killed, and Toxic puts it on a timer; both problems are worsened by its fragility and vulnerability to entry hazards.

Priority Moves: Offensive Pokemon carrying priority moves like Rillaboom, Bisharp, and Dragonite can take advantage of Galarian Darmanitan's middling bulk. However, Pokemon carrying weaker priority moves like Zygarde-10% need it to be heavily chipped before attempting to KO it.

Revenge Killers: Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan can be promptly OHKOed by faster Choice Scarf users like Blacephalon, Terrakion, Latias, and Nihilego. Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan is outsped and OHKOed by a plethora of offensive threats like Tapu Koko, Mega Lopunny, Mega Aerodactyl, and Hydreigon, so it must be extremely wary of them.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Ice)
sets.description:
Galarian Darmanitan is one of the best revenge killers on Ice teams due to its amazing coverage moves and generally high Attack stat boosted by Gorilla Tactics, which make it a decent wallbreaker as well. Flare Blitz lets Galarian Darmanitan KO Steel-types such as Celesteela, Aegislash, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight, which are massive threats to Ice teams. Earthquake provides good coverage against Toxapex, Heatran, and Torkoal, which otherwise completely wall Galarian Darmanitan. Earthquake is also useful for SubToxic Aegislash, as it doesn't activate King's Shield, unlike Flare Blitz. U-turn safely brings in a teammate to deal with a check to Galarian Darmanitan like Rotom-W or Galarian Corsola. Maximum Speed investment along with a Jolly nature allows Galarian Darmanitan to outspeed foes like Mega Aerodactyl, Choice Scarf Landorus-T, and Choice Scarf Excadrill. Galarian Darmanitan should be used to clean weakened teams late-game once bulky walls such as Porygon2 and Swampert are severely weakened or removed. Due to its poor bulk and vulnerability to entry hazards, notably Stealth Rock, it should avoid switching in excessively.

Alolan Ninetales is useful in order to deal with bulky Water-types that pressure Galarian Darmanitan such as Tapu Fini, Rotom-W, and Mega Slowbro with Freeze-Dry, as well as Fighting-types like Keldeo. Additionally, it provides valuable support with Aurora Veil. Avalugg is an extremely useful defensive teammate to deal with physical threats that outspeed Galarian Darmanitan such as Choice Scarf Weavile, Mega Swampert in rain, and Barraskewda in rain. It also removes entry hazards for it with Rapid Spin. Defensive Cloyster can also remove entry hazards and provides Spikes and Toxic Spikes support. Choice Specs Kyurem deals with physically defensive walls such as Porygon2, Galarian Corsola, and Swampert for Galarian Darmanitan due to its power and amazing coverage. Mamoswine is a good offensive partner with Galarian Darmanitan, crippling its usual checks like Galarian Corsola and Porygon2 with Knock Off while acting as a secondary way to deal with Steel teams. It also appreciates Galarian Darmanitan forcing out Steel-types like Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Skarmory, which Mamoswine needs chip damage on to successfully KO. Piloswine can be used instead as a great wall to deal with Fire-types like Choice Scarf Blacephalon and Volcarona thanks to the combination of Thick Fat and Eviolite. It also provides Stealth Rock support for Galarian Darmanitan while dealing with other special attackers like Tapu Koko, Nihilego, and Alolan Raichu. Choice Scarf Weavile can greatly help in the Ghost and Psychic matchups, dealing with faster Choice Scarf users like Latias, Jirachi, and Blacephalon.

sets.name: Choice Band (Ice)
sets.description:
Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan is one of the most lethal wallbreakers on Ice teams due to its Gorilla Tactics-boosted Attack, allowing it to easily break through types with defensive cores such as Dark, Normal, and Poison. Flare Blitz OHKOes troublesome Steel-types like Celesteela, Aegislash, Ferrothorn, and Skarmory after Stealth Rock damage. Earthquake lets Galarian Darmanitan deal with key targets such as Heatran, Toxapex, and Torkoal. U-turn is useful to bring in teammates safely while maintaining offensive momentum. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature lets Galarian Darmanitan outspeed foes such as Mega Garchomp, Nidoking, and unboosted Kommo-o. Galarian Darmanitan should be used as an early-game wallbreaker to take advantage of types with defensive Pokemon, like Dark, Normal, Poison, and punch holes in the opposing team.

Alolan Ninetales is a great teammate to deal with troublesome Fighting-types such as Mega Gallade, Keldeo, and Urshifu-R for Galarian Darmanitan, as well as Dark-types that outspeed it such as Hydreigon and Choice Scarf Weavile, while providing Aurora Veil support. Avalugg is an amazing defensive partner, as it deals with physical attackers that outspeed and KO Galarian Darmanitan like Zeraora, Mega Aerodactyl, and Mega Swampert while also providing Rapid Spin support. Piloswine is an excellent specially defensive wall that can deal with special Fire-types like Volcarona and Blacephalon due to Thick Fat and Eviolite. It also provides Stealth Rock support and deals with additional special attackers that outspeed and threaten Galarian Darmanitan like Latios, Hydreigon, and Thundurus-T. Choice Specs Kyurem can defeat extremely bulky physical walls for Galarian Darmanitan like Galarian Corsola and Porygon2, easing pressure off of it. It also breaks through bulky Water-types like Swampert, Mega Slowbro, and Rotom-W with Freeze-Dry. Choice Scarf Weavile deals with threatening Ghost- and Psychic-types like Gengar, Latias, and Latios.

Ferrothorn.comments:
Other Options

Steel

Ferrothorn can run Stealth Rock instead of Spikes if no other Pokemon on the team has it or it is paired with Skarmory, which can set up its own Spikes. However, it is outclassed as a Stealth Rock setter by Heatran. Knock Off, Toxic, and Thunder Wave have a lot of utility and disadvantage many of Ferrothorn's switch-ins. Knock Off removes valuable items such as Eviolite from Porygon2; Toxic cripples certain bulky switch-ins such as Torkoal, Kyurem, and Landorus-Therian; Thunder Wave cripples fast threats such as Cinderace and Volcarona. It should be noted that running one of these moves forces Ferrothorn to forgo one of its other valuable move slots.

Checks and Counters

Steel

Fire-types and Coverage: Because of Ferrothorn's 4x weakness to Fire, it gets OHKOed by most STAB Fire-type attacks. Even Pokemon with common Fire-type coverage moves such as Nidoking or Clefable can OHKO or 2HKO Ferrothorn.

Fighting-types and Coverage: Although Ferrothorn is not as weak to Fighting-types as it is to Fire-types, many Fighting-types such as Keldeo and Galarian Zapdos threaten to OHKO it. Ferrothorn can, however, use Protect to scout which of these Pokemon are using Choice sets. Breloom is particularly threatening, as it is not vulnerable to any attack from Ferrothorn and can even set up Swords Dance in front of it. Ferrothorn also must be wary of Fighting-type coverage moves such as Focus Blast from Tapu Lele.

Stallbreakers: As Ferrothorn is a very passive Pokemon, certain stallbreakers such as Gliscor easily take advantage of it, although frail stallbreakers such as Urshifu-R will not want to switch in directly and risk a Leech Seed or Power Whip.

Magnet Pull: Magnezone and the less common Alolan Golem can trap Ferrothorn and get rid of it with Hidden Power Fire or Fire Punch, respectively, so they must be carefully played around, though Alolan Golem should be wary of Power Whip.

Mega Sableye: Mega Sableye bounces back Ferrothorn's Spikes and Leech Seed and tanks Power Whip, especially after Ferrothorn is burned by a potential foe like Galarian Corsola.

Wallbreakers: Certain wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Pelipper, Galarian Moltres, and Mega Garchomp power through Ferrothorn even with Leech Seed recovery. Galarian Moltres even sets up on Ferrothorn freely, although it does have to be cautious of being worn down by Leech Seed or crippled by Toxic or Thunder Wave.

sets.name: Defensive (Steel)
sets.description:
Ferrothorn is a great defensive pivot for Steel teams because of its excellent defensive typing, which packs a valuable resistance to Water- and Electric-type attacks, good bulk, and ability to provide entry hazards for its team. Leech Seed is Ferrothorn's main form of recovery and inflicts passive damage on opposing threats such as Toxapex. With Protect, Ferrothorn gets an extra turn of Leech Seed and Leftovers recovery and the ability to scout Choice item users like Diggersby, Mamoswine, and Blacephalon. Power Whip hits Ground- and Water-types; it OHKOes Mega Swampert, Seismitoad, and Gastrodon, and heavily damages Urshifu-R, Excadrill, and Keldeo. It also makes Ferrothorn less passive in general, as it can hit frail offensive threats like Tapu Koko and Tapu Lele hard. Spikes provides a great way to capitalize on other defensive Pokemon that like to switch into Ferrothorn, such as Heatran. The EV spread gives Ferrothorn enough Special Defense to withstand a Focus Blast from Landorus most of the time, and enough Defense to increase its overall effectiveness against physical threats like Choice Band Excadrill and Zeraora.

Every Pokemon on a Steel teams benefits from Ferrothorn's ability to pivot into most Water- and Electric-types and set up Spikes to wear down the opposing team. Flying-types like Celesteela, Skarmory, and Corviknight switch into Fighting-types like Mega Gallade for Ferrothorn. In return, they gain from Ferrothorn checking threats such as Tapu Koko and Kingdra. Heatran is also one of the best partners for Ferrothorn, as it pivots into Fire-type attacks that usually greatly threaten Ferrothorn and beats opposing Steel-types that wall Ferrothorn like Skarmory. Ferrothorn then switches into Water-type attacks in Heatrans stead. Aegislash also helps with Ferrothorn's weaknesses, as it is immune to Fighting-type attacks, and prevents Rapid Spin from removing Ferrothorn's Spikes. Due to its typing, bulk, and ability to set up, Mega Scizor checks certain Fighting-types such as Mega Lopunny. In return, Mega Scizor excels with Spikes support from Ferrothorn, as it becomes that much easier to sweep with Bullet Punch later in the game. Z-Happy Hour Jirachi and Bisharp are other similar late-game sweepers that capitalize off of Ferrothorn's Spikes support and chip damage. Jirachi's Psychic typing makes it a good answer to troublesome Fighting-types like Keldeo and Kommo-o, while Bisharp takes on Psychic- and Ghost-type foes such as Latias, Aegislash, and Latios. Magnezone traps and removes opposing Steel-types like Celesteela, which threatens Ferrothorn with Flamethrower, and opposing Ferrothorn, which may set up its own entry hazards. Scarf Excadrill revenge kills Fire-types like Blacephalon, provides a secondary check to Electric-types, and pairs well with Ferrothorn's resistance to Water-types and Spikes support for cleaning up late-game.

Mandibuzz.comments:
Other Options

Dark

Toxic can be used over U-turn to cripple defensive Pokemon like Porygon2, Hippowdon, and Avalugg; however, Mandibuzz then misses out on U-turn, which is very much appreciated thanks to it being able to swing in momentum for free against a predicted switch-in. Taunt is also an option over U-turn to prevent walls like Toxapex, Blissey, and Celesteela from using status moves, helping Mandibuzz wear them down. Knock Off can be used over Foul Play to annoy walls like Toxapex, Porygon2, and Blissey, but without Foul Play, Mandibuzz cannot punish threatening setup sweepers like Azumarill and Mega Gallade.

Checks and Counters

Dark

Fairy-types: Fairy-types like Mega Diancie, Tapu Lele, and Hatterene have little to no trouble beating Mandibuzz.

Status: As a defensive Pokemon that is intended to be used for longer games, Mandibuzz finds itself susceptible to statuses like Toxic poison and paralysis. Toxic puts it on a timer, while paralysis can prevent it from performing its role effectively.

Super Effective Attacks: Super effective attacks from Pokemon like Alolan Raichu, Terrakion, and Galarian Darmanitan can make Mandibuzz extremely weakened or even OHKO it.

Wallbreakers: Mandibuzz has trouble facing extremely powerful wallbreakers like Mega Heracross and Greninja, which can break it apart easily.

Stallbreakers: Common stallbreakers like Gliscor and Mew can completely shut down Mandibuzz with Taunt, cripple it with Toxic or Will-O-Wisp, and prevent it from recovering its health.

Walls: Mandibuzz struggles to get past certain walls on its own such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Zapdos, as even Taunt variants cannot stop them due to their massive bulk.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot (Dark)
sets.description:
Thanks to its good defensive stats, neutrality against Fighting- and Bug-type attacks, and good utility moves, Mandibuzz performs the role of a premiere utility support Pokemon for Dark-type teams, making it usable even on hyper offense archetypes. Foul Play lets Mandibuzz greatly damage physical attackers like Mega Gallade, Dragonite, and Victini while also punishing setup sweepers like Mega Scizor, Mega Charizard X, and Excadrill. Roost allows Mandibuzz to keep itself healthy, giving it longevity and thus allowing it to be an effective defensive pivot throughout the game. Defog is a good utility move that is greatly appreciated by teammates of Mandibuzz, as it keeps them safe from entry hazards like Sticky Web and Toxic Spikes that may plague the entire team. Lastly, U-turn lets Mandibuzz gain momentum on a predicted switch-in against it and bring in an appropriate teammate in the battle safely. 16 Speed EVs let it outspeed Adamant Belly Drum Azumarill and check it with Foul Play. The rest of the EVs are invested into HP and Defense to optimize its overall bulk. Heavy-Duty Boots is used as an item so that Mandibuzz can freely switch in without getting chipped down by Stealth Rock, making it harder for the opposing team to wear it down. Overcoat makes Mandibuzz immune to Spore from Breloom and Amoonguss while also keeping it safe from sand and hail damage.

Teammates like Weavile and Greninja like Mandibuzz switching in against physical attacks aimed at them from Pokemon like Excadrill and it creating momentum with U-turn to bring them in safely as well as clearing entry hazards away and allowing them to wallbreak foes much more effectively. Specially defensive Tyranitar can form a defensive core with Mandibuzz, since it can take on special attacks aimed at Mandibuzz while also providing Stealth Rock and Thunder Wave support. Mega Sableye takes the pressure off of Mandibuzz and can check threats like Mega Gallade that can otherwise break apart Dark-type teams, additionally bouncing back any status move aimed at Mandibuzz from Pokemon like Gastrodon and Swampert. It also does great against opposing entry hazard setters like Tyranitar, Blissey, and Ferrothorn. Hydreigon can take care of walls like Toxapex and Hippowdon that Mandibuzz can struggle against. Alolan Muk and Bisharp can cover Fairy-types like Clefable. The former can also absorb special attacks aimed at Mandibuzz well and act as a good wincon when running Curse, while the latter is a good setup sweeper and wallbreaker against defensive types like Poison. Zarude can cover Water-type teams and beat threatening Pokemon like Urshifu-R.

Volcarona.comments:
Other Options

Bug

Flamethrower can be used over Fire Blast due to its higher accuracy and PP, but Fire Blast is preferred due to its higher power and stronger Inferno Overdrive. After a Quiver Dance boost, Fire Blast also guarantees OHKOs against threats like Landorus-T and Zeraora while Flamethrower is a very low roll to OHKO. Hidden Power Electric can work over Hidden Power Ground to deal with Mantine better, but then Volcarona struggles against Heatran. Bug Buzz can be used in the last moveslot as a secondary STAB move that deals with Dark- and Psychic-types such as Hydregion and Latias, but Volcarona's teammates already takes care of those Pokemon adequately. Roost can also be used for extra longevity but it generally prefers its coverage moves to effectively sweep teams.

Checks and Counters

Bug

Status: Status such as paralysis and Toxic poison greatly cripples Volcarona as a sweeper, with paralysis leaving it revenge killed even with Speed boosts.

Revenge Killers: Faster Choice Scarf users such as Nihilego and Terrakion are able to OHKO Volcarona even after a Quiver Dance due to their high Speed stats and super effective attacks.

Priority Users: Pokemon such as Azumarill and Mega Pinsir threaten to KO Volcarona after some prior chip damage thanks to their strong priority moves.

Haze Users and Phazers: Pokemon such as Mantine and Empoleon are tough for Volcarona to break through, as they can live a hit and remove its boosts with Haze and Roar, respectively, although Empoleon needs to be careful of a Inferno Overdrive KOing it after some prior chip damage.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Special walls such as Blissey, Mantine, Araquanid, and specially defensive Tyranitar take very little damage from Volcarona's attacks, and the former two can threaten it with Toxic, while the latter two can OHKO it with their STAB moves. Volcarona lacking Hidden Power Ground struggles greatly against Heatran, which takes little or no damage from any of Volcarona's moves while threatening it with Toxic.

Stealth Rock: Volcarona running a Z-Crystal instead of Heavy-Duty Boots struggles greatly to switch in and set up with Stealth Rock up.

sets.name: Quiver Dance (Bug)
sets.description:
Great Special Attack and Speed alongside access to Quiver Dance make Volcarona one of the best setup sweepers in the metagame, helping Bug in tough matchups such as Steel, Electric, and Poison. Fire Blast hits walls such as Gliscor and Mandibuzz hard and beats Steel-types such as Celesteela and Ferrothorn. Psychic helps Volcarona in dealing with troublesome Poison types such as Toxapex. Hidden Power Ground bypasses Heatran after its Air Balloon has been popped, which can otherwise wall it. Giga Drain can be used instead to nail bulky Water- and Ground-types such as Gastrodon, Slowking, and Hippowdon while also granting a bit of recovery. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Volcarona to switch in throughout the game despite its huge Stealth Rock weakness. Volcarona should try setting up against a passive Pokemon like Toxapex or Mandibuzz once its checks such as Mantine are weakened or KOed, allowing it to pull off a clean sweep. Maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature allows Volcarona to outspeed Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Mimikyu unboosted while outspeeding Choice Scarf users such as Excadrill and Landorus-T after a Quiver Dance boost.

Choice Scarf users like Buzzwole and Heracross are great partners to revenge kill faster threats such as Garchomp and Mega Lopunny. Volcarona in return can weaken opposing teams, allowing them to clean with Beast Boost and Moxie boosts, respectively. Heracross can also Pursuit trap offensive Heatran and pop its Air Balloon, thus allowing Volcarona to KO it with Hidden Power Ground, while Buzzwole helps against Dragon- and Ground-types like Landorus and Zygarde-10% with Ice Punch. Shuckle provides Stealth Rock and Sticky Web support; Stealth Rock chips foes while also breaking Focus Sash and Sturdy, while Sticky Web allows Volcarona to outspeed Choice Scarf users like Greninja and Nihilego after a boost. Araquanid can switch into strong special Water-type attacks directed towards Volcarona while also checking Fire-types such as Mega Charizard Y that resist Volcarona's coverage. Galvantula is also helpful in beating Water- and Flying-types such as Toxapex and Mantine. Furthermore, both Araquanid and Galvantula can also provide Sticky Web support. Scizor is great to deal with Rock-types like Tyranitar and Mega Diancie and Pursuit trap threats to Volcarona such as Choice Scarf Latias, and Choice Band Victini after the V-Create Speed drop. Mega Scizor also forms a great offensive core with Volcarona, taking on special walls such as Blissey while Volcarona handles physical ones such as Celesteela and Hippowdon. Mega Pinsir is helpful against Choice Scarf users like Keldeo and Zarude, which could threaten Volcarona, with its strong priority in Quick Attack while also beating special walls like Tyranitar for it. Scolipede helps deal with offensive Fire- and Rock-types like Blacephalon and Nihilego due to its coverage.

sets.name: Z-Move (Bug)
sets.description:
Teams with good entry hazard removal can use a Z-Crystal of choice on Volcarona instead of Heavy-Duty Boots, which lets it work as a wallbreaker that breaks through Pokemon like Hippowdon and Toxapex after a Quiver Dance boost. Quiver Dance notably allows Volcarona to outspeed threats like Tapu Koko and Zygarde-10% after a boost. Fire Blast hits neutral targets such as Zapdos for good damage while nailing Grass- and Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Aegislash. Firium Z turns Fire Blast into a one-time nuke in form of Inferno Overdrive, allowing it to OHKO Pokemon such as Mega Venasaur and specially defensive Zapdos after a boost. Volcarona running Firium Z uses Hidden Power Ground to better deal with Steel-type teams by beating Heatran, while Psychium Z variants run Psychic to for strong Shattered Psyche that bypasses one of its biggest checks in Toxapex. Giga Drain helps in hitting bulky Water-types like Slowking and Swampert while acting as a semi-reliable form of recovery. Volcarona should avoid switching in when Stealth Rock is up or getting poisoned or paralyzed, as both greatly harm its sweeping potential. Its checks like Mantine and Tyranitar should also be taken care of before it attempts to pull off a sweep. Maximum Speed investment alongside a Timid nature makes Volcarona outspeed threats like Choice Scarf Excadrill after a boost and Speed tie other base 100s like Galarian Zapdos unboosted.

Armaldo and Forretress are mandatory teammates for Z-Move Volcarona, as they can clear Stealth Rock with Rapid Spin while providing their own Stealth Rock support, giving Volcarona an easier time securing KOs. Armaldo can check Fire-types like Choice Scarf Victini with Stone Edge, while Forretress can further bring in Volcarona safely with a slow Volt Switch and also takes on Rock-types such as Terrakion with Gyro Ball. Mega Scizor is great to take on threating Pokemon such as Mega Diancie, Nihilego, and Terrakion with Bullet Punch while also beating special walls such as Mantine and Tyranitar that Volcarona struggles with. Choice Scarf Heracross or Buzzwole further helps Volcarona in dealing with faster threats such as Mega Lopunny and Zarude. Additionally, Heracross can Pursuit trap offensive Heatran and Victini, popping the former's Air Balloon for Volcarona running Hidden Power Ground and potentially removing the latter after a V-Create, while Buzzwole can help against troublesome Dragon- and Flying-types such as Garchomp and Landorus-T with Ice Punch. Mega Heracross is good with Volcarona lacking Hidden Power Ground, as it can take on Heatran. It also forms a good wallbreaking core with Volcarona, helping in the Dark, Normal, and Rock matchups, which Volcarona puts little work in. Specially defensive Araquanid can be useful in dealing with Fire-types such as opposing Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y. Sticky Web support from the likes of Araquanid and Galvantula is greatly appreciated, as it allows Volcarona to outspeed troublesome Pokemon like Choice Scarf Nihilego and Greninja at +1. Choice Band Scizor is an offensive pivot for Volcarona that Pursuit traps Choice Band Victini after V-Create.

Cobalion.comments:
Other Options

Fighting

Cobalion can opt for Rocky Helmet in lieu of Leftovers to chip down and punish U-turn users like Mega Scizor and other physical attackers. Both Chople Berry and Occa Berry are options as well, mainly helping against threats like Mega Lopunny and Victini, respectively. However, any other item means that Cobalion loses its only method of recovery. Cobalion can also opt for a more offensive set with Life Orb. However, its middling offensive stats usually leave it unable to do any significant damage.

Checks and Counters

Fighting

Burns: Burns heavily cripple Cobalion, reducing its already-low damage output and negating its recovery from Leftovers.

Stallbreakers: Stallbreakers such as Zarude, Mew, and Gliscor have little to no trouble dealing with Cobalion, as Iron Head does very little damage to them.

Wallbreakers: Despite Cobalion'ns decent defensive stats, powerful wallbreakers like Choice Specs Tapu Koko and Mega Gallade that outspeed it can comfortably deal large amounts of damage to it with their powerful STAB moves.

sets.name: Utility (Fighting)
sets.description:
A good Speed tier, an amazing Defense stat, good utility moves in Taunt, Stealth Rock, and Thunder Wave, and an amazing secondary typing in Steel make Cobalion one of the best defensive pivots Fighting has to offer. Stealth Rock primarily helps against threats weak to it like Choice Specs Zapdos and Alolan Ninetales. Cobalion's decent defensive stats and good Speed mean it can successfully set Stealth Rock more often than not. Iron Head helps against Fairy-types that threaten Fighting-type teams like Mega Diancie and Tapu Lele. Taunt blocks foes from using Taunt and recovery moves, as well as blocking their own entry hazards or Defog to remove Cobalion's Stealth Rock. Thunder Wave is used to cripple faster offensive threats that Cobalion fails to do much against like Deoxys-S and Latios. Volt Switch can be used in lieu of Thunder Wave, making Coballion a great defensive pivot while maintaining offensive momentum. Justified allows it to switch into weak Dark-type attacks from the likes of Mandibuzz and gain an Attack boost. A Jolly nature allows Cobalion to outspeed key threats like both Urshifu-R, Kyurem, Hydreigon, non-Choice Scarf Blacephalon, and Tapu Lele while Speed tying with Pokemon such as Keldeo and Terrakion.

All of Cobalion's teammates appreciate it reliably setting up Stealth Rock while also being able to paralyze faster foes for them. Terrakion and Keldeo reliably deal with Fire-types like Volcarona and Victini that threaten Cobalion. Keldeo can also threaten Ground-types that threaten Cobalion such as Landorus and Excadrill. Both Terrakion and Keldeo also appreciate. Volt Switch Cobalion reliably pivoting into them, as do Mega Gallade and Kommo-o looking for good setup opportunities. Mega Gallade also eases matchups such as Poison and Steel where Cobalion fails to do anything significant, and Kommo-o has Taunt to take on opposing walls like Toxapex and Celesteela that deal with Cobalion. Urshifu-S, Heracross, and Buzzwole fit well on Fighting teams because they aid greatly in the Psychic-type matchup. Hawlucha is able to ease the Fighting-type mirror matchup while taking care of Fighting-types that threaten Cobalion, like opposing Keldeo and Choice Scarf users such as Heracross and Buzzwole. Lastly, Breloom can be opted for on certain teams to ease matchups such as Ground and Water where Cobalion fails to do anything of significance besides setting Stealth Rock.

Landorus.comments:
Other Options

Ground

Rock Polish enables Landorus to outspeed foes like Choice Scarf Blacephalon, Choice Scarf Greninja, and Tapu Koko, making it an excellent sweeper. Calm Mind can be used to increase Landorus's power to extreme levels, letting it better damage walls like Swampert and Mega Venusaur. Rock Slide allows Landorus to nail Flying-types like Mantine, Zapdos, and Mega Charizard Y without relying on Gravity. However, replacing Focus Blast with either move makes Landorus unable to deal with foes that it would otherwise beat, such as Hydreigon, Kyurem, and Porygon2. Replacing Gravity, on the other hand, makes Landorus unable to support its teammates or handle Pokemon like Skarmory and Celesteela.

Checks and Counters

Ground

Specially Defensive Walls: Specially defensive walls like Blissey and Slowking can act as sturdy checks to Landorus; Blissey can wear it down with Seismic Toss and Toxic, and Slowking can hit it with Scald. Slowking is also able to shrug off the damage Landorus inflicts due to Regenerator. However, Blissey has a chance of getting 2HKOed by Focus Blast.

Water-types: Defensive Water-types such as Slowbro, Tapu Fini, and Gastrodon can withstand an Earth Power from Landorus and force it out by dealing heavy damage to it with their STAB moves, while offensive Water-types such as Greninja, Mega Swampert, and Keldeo all outspeed and KO Landorus.

Ice-types: Ice-types like Alolan Ninetales, Weavile, and Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan all outspeed and threaten Landorus, while Mamoswine can revenge kill it using Ice Shard. However, slower ones like Kyurem and Piloswine take a lot from Focus Blast, and all Ice-types need to be careful of switching into it.

Faster Pokemon: Due to Landorus's only average Speed stat, faster Pokemon like Mega Gallade, Latios, and Blacephalon all force Landorus to switch out, as they can otherwise deal huge amounts of damage to it with their STAB moves. However, Landorus can outspeed and dispatch most revenge killers with Rock Polish.

sets.name: Wallbreaker (Ground)
sets.description:
Landorus is the premier special wallbreaker on Ground teams, capable of beating troublesome foes like Ferrothorn, Tapu Bulu, and Porygon2 through its amazing coverage moves boosted by the combination of Sheer Force and Life Orb. Earth Power is Landorus's most powerful move, pressuring walls like Mega Sableye, Slowbro, and Gastrodon. Sludge Wave threatens the Grass-types that resist Earth Power, such as Tapu Bulu and Celebi, while OHKOing Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele and Hatterene. Focus Blast nails Dark-, Ice-, and Normal-types, like Hydreigon, Kyurem, and Porygon2, while hitting Skarmory without relying on Gravity and targeting Ferrothorn. Gravity removes Ground immunities from foes that would otherwise check Landorus such as Celesteela, Rotom-W, and Zapdos, making Landorus's Earth Power and its teammates' Ground-type STAB moves much more spammable. It also ensures Focus Blast always lands, heightening Landorus's reliability in the Normal, Dark, and Steel matchups. Life Orb works well in tandem with Sheer Force, which negates Life Orb's recoil and adds to its damage boost. A Timid nature is needed in order for Landorus to outspeed common foes like Victini, Tapu Lele, and Hydreigon.

Excadrill pairs extremely well with Landorus, as it can deal with specially defensive walls that Landorus struggles with, such as Blissey and Slowking, while outspeeding fast threats to Landorus like Choice Scarf Weavile, Tapu Koko, and Mega Lopunny when under sand. In return, Landorus can provide valuable support to Excadrill with Gravity, letting it beat its usual checks like Skarmory, Celesteela, and Porygon2, in addition to dealing with physically defensive foes such as Porygon2 and Mega Sableye for it. Hippowdon provides a switch-in against certain foes that can outspeed and threaten Landorus such as Mega Gallade, Cinderace, and Garchomp. It also wears down most foes with Stealth Rock and Sand Stream, which Landorus generally appreciates. Gastrodon and Seismitoad both switch completely freely into Water-type attacks from the likes of Mega Swampert, Keldeo, and Mantine for Landorus. Gastrodon is also able to reliably take and heal off most other moves from Water-types thanks to its high bulk and Recover, while Seismitoad is one of the best ways for Ground teams to offensively deal with them. Mamoswine deals with troublesome Dragon-types such as Latias, Mega Latios, and Dragonite as well as Flying-types that Landorus relies on Gravity in order to beat, like Zapdos and Dragonite. Garchomp and Mega Garchomp are fearsome wallbreakers that pressure specially defensive walls like Blissey and Slowking while providing a Water neutrality. Mega Steelix's absurdly high Defense stat and Steel typing make it a fierce bulky sweeper with Curse that can consistently check Azumarill and take on Grass-, Normal-, and Dragon-types for Landorus, such as Rillaboom, Blissey, and Mega Altaria.

Klefki.comments:
Other Options

Fairy

Fairy Lock can be used to bring in a setup sweeper to take advantage of a trapped foe if Klefki is about to faint, though you miss out on entry hazards or other utility.

Checks and Counters

Fairy

Magic Bounce: Mega Diancie, Mega Sableye, and Hatterene can all bounce back Thunder Wave and Spikes, leaving Klefki only being able to set up dual screens.

Taunt + Trick users: Since Klefki has primarily utility moves, it can be completely shut down by Taunt users such as Tornadus-T, Mew, and Heatran. Mew can also remove Klefki's Light Clay with Knock Off, shortening the duration of its dual screens. Latios, Rotom-W, and Gengar are examples of Pokemon that can utilize Trick to give Klefki unwanted Choice items, locking it into one move and making it unable to set up past that.

Defog Users: Defog users such as Mantine can easily clear entry hazards and dual screens off the battlefield, but it needs to be wary of getting crippled by Thunder Wave. Some users, however, such as Gliscor, Rotom-W and Mandibuzz are immune to Thunder Wave, leaving Klefki unable to do anything against them.

Super Effective Attacks: Fire- and Ground-types have hard-hitting STAB attacks that can power through Klefki easily, not giving it enough time to fully set up dual screens or Spikes. Mega Charizard Y can OHKO Klefki behind Light Screen with a sun-boosted Fire Blast.

sets.name: Dual Screens (Fairy)
sets.description:
Klefki provides great support to Fairy teams with priority dual screens and Spikes thanks to its ability Prankster. Foul Play checks physical setup sweepers such as Mega Scizor, Dragonite, and Mimikyu. Thunder Wave can be used to cripple opposing threats such as Mega Charizard Y, Mega Aerodactyl, Nihilego, and Cinderace. Klefki's defensive typing is appreciated by Fairy teams, since it is immune to Poison-type attacks and can take on Steel-type attacks such as Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch comfortably. Maximum HP and Defense investment with a Bold nature ensures Klefki has as much physical bulk as possible.

All of Klefki's teammates appreciate everything it provides, most notably setup sweepers. Azumarill is a good pairing, since it can take on Ground-types and safely set up with Belly Drum alongside Normalium Z or Sitrus Berry behind dual screens. Swords Dance Tapu Bulu is also able to take on Ground-types and appreciates dual screens as well, since it is easy for it to get off Substitute and set up. Mimikyu benefits from dual screens, as it can survive a few extra turns after setting up, even after its Disguise is broken. Mega Diancie makes for another great teammate to pair with Klefki because it can bounce back opposing entry hazards and has good coverage such as Mystical Fire to pick off Ferrothorn and other bulky Steel-types thanks to chip damage from Spikes. Wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele and Choice Band Tapu Bulu appreciate Klefki's ability to cripple threats that would normally outspeed them, such as Gengar and Mega Aerodactyl. Tapu Koko can be used as a pivot to get Klefki on the battlefield safely if switching in with it is not optimal. Clefable can also provide extra utility in the form of setting Stealth Rocks and item removal with Knock Off.

Avalugg.comments:
Other Options

Ice

Mirror Coat works well in tandem with Sturdy, allowing Avalugg to unexpectedly OHKO foes when it's at full health such as Magnezone, Keldeo, and Heatran, which all threaten Ice teams. Iron Defense allows Avalugg to consistently wall threats such as Mega Lopunny, Mega Scizor, and Alolan Golem while simultaneously boosting the power of Body Press. Toxic can slowly put offensive foes on a timer, but is hard to fit.

Checks and Counters

Ice

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Volcarona, Victini, Blacephalon, and Mega Charizard Y can KO Avalugg with their powerful STAB moves.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Keldeo, Mega Gallade, Kommo-o, and Terrakion can deal a good amount of damage to Avalugg with their STAB moves. However, after an Iron Defense boost, Avalugg can withstand a few hits from Terrakion and retaliate with a boosted Body Press.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Aegislash, Celesteela, and Heatran can beat Avalugg with ease. Aegislash completely walls Avalugg and can stall it with Substitute and Toxic or set up with Swords Dance, Celesteela defeats it with Leech Seed, Toxic, and Flamethrower, and Heatran has Fire-type STAB moves.

Rock-types: If Avalugg lacks a move they fear, then Rock-types such as Mega Tyranitar, Alolan Golem, and Mega Aerodactyl force Avalugg to take their powerful STAB moves. Nihilego is an especially great check to Avalugg, since it's a special attacker. However, Avalugg can beat Mega Aerodactyl with Avalanche and the other aforementioned Rock-types with Body Press.

Status: Toxic wears down Avalugg, making it harder for it to check Pokemon. Burn's Attack drop makes it difficult for Avalugg to apply pressure on Pokemon.

Special Attackers: Avalugg's Special Defense stat is poor, making it vulnerable to many prominent special attackers in the tier, such as Tapu Koko, Landorus, Blacephalon, Tapu Lele, and Latios to name a few.

Ghost-types: Ghost-types spinblock Avalugg and are immune to Body Press, limiting Avalugg without Avalanche to Roar and Recover. A few Ghost-types, such as Aegislash, Blacephalon, and Gengar, can completely force Avalugg out.

sets.name: Defensive Rapid Spin (Ice)
sets.description:
Avalugg's incredible physical bulk, access to reliable recovery, and Rapid Spin make it a defensive staple that can deal with threats to Ice teams such as Excadrill, Bisharp, Tyranitar, and Mega Aerodactyl. Rapid Spin allows Avalugg to remove opposing entry hazards for its teammates. Roar phazes setup sweepers like Mimikyu and Mega Altaria that Avalugg cannot touch with Body Press, or Mega Tyranitar if it runs Avalanche. Body Press works well in conjunction with Avalugg's high Defense stat, letting it hit Steel-, Dark-, and Rock-types such as Ferrothorn, Excadrill, Bisharp, and Tyranitar. However, Avalanche allows Avalugg to deal good damage to Zapdos, Landorus, and Tapu Bulu that it otherwise relies on Roar to handle. Heavy-Duty Boots is invaluable, as it provides an immunity to entry hazards, especially Stealth Rock, to prevent Avalugg from being chipped and breaking its Sturdy. Avalugg should generally avoid status aliments such as Toxic and getting hit by Knock Off, since it will be too weakened to check the aforementioned Pokemon. Sturdy allows Avalugg to survive moves from powerful attackers like Hydreigon, Keldeo, and Victini, successfully using Rapid Spin against them.

All of Avalugg's teammates appreciate its defensive utility, especially since Ice teams are vulnerable to entry hazards. Alolan Ninetales can deal with Fighting-types such as Kommo-o, Keldeo, and Mega Gallade. Additionally, it provides defensive support through Aurora Veil, giving Avalugg an opportunity to wall threats such as Mega Lopunny, Terrakion, Excadrill, and Bisharp. Choice Scarf Weavile is particularly useful for revenge killing Ghost-types such as Aegislash, Blacephalon, Gengar, and Spectrier that spinblock Avalugg, trapping them with Pursuit. Piloswine forms a nice defensive core with Avalugg; Thick Fat and Eviolite let Piloswine take on Fire-types such as Volcarona, Blacephalon, and Mega Charizard Y, it can set Stealth Rock to let Avalugg chip down foes with Roar, and it can absorb attacks from most special attackers like Tapu Koko, Alolan Raichu, Hydreigon, and Nihilego. Galarian Darmanitan is capable of revenge killing Steel-types like Aegislash, Celesteela, and Heatran with the combination of Flare Blitz and Earthquake, especially if it's running a Choice Scarf. Cloyster especially appreciates Rapid Spin support from Avalugg, as it can preserve its occasional Focus Sash and get an easier sweep with Shell Smash.

Diancie.comments:
Other Options

Fairy

Rock Polish can be used to make Mega Diancie into a setup sweeper. When using it, customize Mega Diancie's attacks to take on certain types you want it to act as a wincon against. Stealth Rock can be used over a coverage move but is difficult to justify.

Checks and Counters

Fairy

Super Effective Coverage: If Mega Diancie cannot OHKO a Pokemon with super effective coverage such as Mega Steelix, it will most likely drop in one hit due to its poor natural defenses.

Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Excadrill and Greninja can easily outspeed and OHKO Mega Diancie with their STAB moves and coverage, respectively.

Priority Attackers: Pokemon such as Mega Scizor and Azumarill can threaten to OHKO Mega Diancie with their priority attacks in Bullet Punch and Aqua Jet due to its poor natural defenses.

Special Walls: Since Mega Diancie primarily relies on its special attacks, specially defensive Pokemon capable of taking Diamond Storm can easily wall it, such as Celesteela.

sets.name: All-out Attacker (Fairy)
sets.description:
Mega Diancie is a phenomenal asset to Fairy teams, with Magic Bounce to deflect entry hazards and status, wide coverage, and good offensive prowess backed by a great natural Speed tier. Moonblast is Mega Diancie's most spammable attack, taking on Pokemon such as Mega Sableye, Latios, and Keldeo. Diamond Storm allows Mega Diancie to hit Pokemon such as Volcarona, Tornadus-T, and Alolan Ninetales for super effective damage and fish for Defense boosts. Mystical Fire targets Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Celesteela switching in, and Mega Scizor if it attempts to use Swords Dance on Mega Diancie. Alternatively, Psychic hits Poison-type Pokemon such as Mega Venusaur. Diamond Storm + Psychic gives Mega Diancie 2HKO all Poison-type Pokemon as well. Hidden Power Ice allows Mega Diancie to take on Gliscor and Landorus. Earth Power, in conjunction with Mystical Fire, can be used instead for Mega Diancie to be very effective against Steel teams: it OHKOes Heatran, Excadrill, and Magnezone, hits Aegislash the hardest, and takes on threats such as weakened Mega Steelix. Diamond Storm + Mystical Fire + Hidden Power Ice allows Mega Diancie to hit all Flying-type Pokemon for super effective damage. Maximum Special Attack and Speed EVs, alongside a Naive nature, allow Mega Diancie to be as fast as Latios and hit as hard as possible specially while not decreasing Diamond Storm's damage output. Clear Body allows Diancie to ignore Sticky Web prior to Mega Evolution.

All of Mega Diancie's teammates appreciate its offensive prowess and access to Magic Bounce, especially because Fairy teams tend not to carry entry hazard removal. Klefki can set Spikes for Mega Diancie, allowing it to break through Pokemon such as Focus Sash Garchomp, and checks setup sweepers like Mega Scizor thanks to Foul Play. Additionally, screens from Klefki make Mega Diancie harder to revenge kill. On top of that, Klefki can paralyze faster threats such as Mega Aerodactyl for it. Tapu Koko can take on threats to Mega Diancie such as Celesteela while also stallbreaking against Pokemon such as Mega Venusaur with Taunt, allowing Mega Diancie to take it out with Psychic. Tapu Lele can take on Poison-type Pokemon such as Toxapex and Nidoking for Mega Diancie. Additionally, it sets Psychic Terrain, preventing priority moves such as Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch from OHKOing Mega Diancie. Tapu Bulu can take on Electric-, Ground-, and Water-type Pokemon for Mega Diancie such as Tapu Koko, Hippowdon, and Swampert with its Grass-type STAB moves, as well as providing passive recovery due to Grassy Terrain. Azumarill can help Mega Diancie take on Fire teams and handles Ground- and Steel-type Pokemon for it with Aqua Jet, and Brick Break to take out Melmetal, after Belly Drum. Mimikyu can easily take on Psychic teams for Mega Diancie after a Swords Dance, OHKO bulkier Pokemon with boosted Shadow Claw, and OHKO faster Pokemon like Choice Scarf Latias with boosted Shadow Sneak. Togekiss can be used to take on Grass-type Pokemon for Mega Diancie, such as Rillaboom, Mega Venusaur, and Ferrothorn, which Fairy teams struggle with. Togekiss can also help break past Steel-type Pokemon such as Melmetal with its coverage in Fire Blast and Aura Sphere. Clefable can provide Stealth Rock support for Mega Diancie to secure crucial damage rolls against the likes of Excadrill and Gliscor.

Toxapex.comments:
Other Options

Water

Poison Jab targets Calm Mind Tapu Fini, while Sludge Bomb targets Tapu Bulu. Knock Off can be used to cripple Pokemon such as Galarian Corsola; all three options are niche options that can be used over Scald. Eject Button can be used on rain teams, allowing Toxapex to effectively generate momentum for the team without unnecessarily risking the offensive Pokemon while still regaining health through Regenerator.

Checks and Counters

Water

Super Effective Coverage: Super Effective STAB attacks such as Latios's Psychic, Landorus-T's Earthquake, and Thundurus-T's Thunderbolt easily break through Toxapex.

Stallbreakers: Taunt and Trick users such as Gliscor and Latias prevent Toxapex from freely using its utility moves, hindering its ability to act as a wall.

Wallbreakers: Strong attackers with neutral coverage such as Choice Band Rillaboom easily beat Toxapex.

sets.name: Defensive (Water)
sets.description:
Toxapex is the premier defensive pivot for Water teams, as its good utility options and natural bulk alongside Regenerator allow it to constantly switch in through the game and support its teammates. Scald prevents Toxapex from becoming too passive while also allowing it to fish for burns against physical threats such as Rillaboom. Recover allows Toxapex to stay healthy through the match, especially alongside Regenerator recovery. Toxic Spikes allow Toxapex to support its offensive teammates by poisoning and chipping grounded foes. Toxic Spikes are especially useful in matchups such as Fairy, Psychic, and Dragon. Toxic, on the other hand, allows Toxapex to hit Flying-types and Levitate users such as Zapdos, Mega Latias, and Hydreigon, which can be a problem for Water teams. Haze allows Toxapex to check setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Mega Charizard X, Autotomize Celesteela, and Swords Dance Aegislash. Baneful Bunker can be used to scout Choice-locked attackers such as Choice Specs Tapu Koko, gain recovery, and further take advantage of Toxic. Baneful Bunker can also help provide useful chip against physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny. Regenerator allows Toxapex to act as a sponge by switching into attacks and regaining health upon switching out.

Toxapex's teammates appreciate its ability to act as a defensive pivot, remove Toxic Spikes from the field, and set its own Toxic Spikes. Slowking and Toxapex forms a great Regenerator core; under Toxapex's Toxic Spikes, Future Sight from Slowking is nearly impossible for opposing Pokemon to handle. Slowking also acts as a specially defensive wall for Toxapex and provides a crucial resistance to Psychic-type attacks such as Tapu Lele's Psychic and Future Sight. Pelipper, Mantine, and Rotom-W are important teammates to Toxapex, as they provide Ground immunities and Defog. Mantine allows Toxapex to use Baneful Bunker, as it can check Azumarill with Haze. Mantine's Haze also allows it to check a plethora of other setup sweepers such as Nasty Plot Hydreigon and Volcarona. Swampert provides Electric immunity and Stealth Rock. Additionally, it can also take on Electric-types such as Zeraora with Earthquake. Offensive teammates such as Greninja, Mega Swampert, Urshifu-R, and Mega Sharpedo appreciate Toxapex's ability to wear down the opposing team, allowing them to clean up late-game. Defensive setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Suicune and Mega Slowbro also appreciate Toxic Spikes. They can specifically take advantage of their bulk and Toxic poison to set up with more ease. Gastrodon and Empoleon are other defensive teammates that can help Toxapex wear down the foe. Empoleon can remove items with Knock Off, while Gastrodon can run Sticky Hold, allowing it to switch into Trick for Toxapex. Gastrodon also provides immunity to Electric-type attacks directed at Toxapex.

Mimikyu.comments:
Other Options

Ghost

Wood Hammer can be used instead of Drain Punch or Shadow Claw to let Mimikyu lure in and OHKO bulky Water / Ground Pokemon such as Swampert, Gastrodon, and Seismitoad. However, it has generally no purpose outside of that, making it less useful than Drain Punch or Shadow Claw. Mimikyu can run Mimikium Z or Ghostium Z to nuke walls that would otherwise wall it, like Hippowdon and Toxapex, after a Swords Dance boost. However, without using either of these Z-Moves, Mimikyu is much weaker without Life Orb.

Fairy

An Adamant nature can be opted for over Jolly, but it comes at the cost of underspeeding some key threats, such as Tapu Lele and Excadrill.

Checks and Counters

Ghost

Physically Defensive Walls: Walls such as Toxapex, Avalugg, and Hippowdon are very threatening to Mimikyu. Toxapex can get rid of its Swords Dance boosts with Haze while threatening to burn it with Scald, Avalugg wears it down with Avalanche, and Hippowdon can phaze it with Whirlwind and also wear it down with Earthquake.

Revenge Killers: Revenge killers that can take a Shadow Sneak such as Greninja, Weavile, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele due to Psychic Terrain can deal with Mimikyu. Weavile's Triple Axel can also break through Disguise. However, Mimikyu can defeat these revenge killers bar Weavile if Disguise is intact.

Status: Burn heavily cripples Mimikyu making it unable to revenge kill or sweep properly. Toxic puts it on a timer, making it worn down easily in conjuction with Life Orb. Paralysis significantly slows down Mimikyu, making it unable to outspeed a lot of foes and easily revenge killed.

Phazers: Because Mimikyu is mainly reliant on Swords Dance in order to sweep, Haze and Whirlwind users like Mantine, Toxapex, Hippowdon, and Skarmory can easily deal with it by forcing it out.

Mold Breaker: Mold Breaker Excadrill is particularly threatening to Mimikyu, as it ignores Disguises and OHKOes it with Iron Head or Earthquake. However, it doesn't like switching into Drain Punch. Mega Gyarados is also a threat to Mimikyu, as it can OHKO it after a Dragon Dance boost and stay in its regular form to set up and avoid taking super effective damage from Play Rough.

Fairy

Physical Walls: Mimikyu is easily walled by physical walls such as Skarmory, Celesteela and Porygon2 due to its middling Attack stat, and the latter two can threaten to KO with Heavy Slam and Foul Play, respectively.

Haze Users and Phazers: Due to its mediocre Attack stat, Mimikyu heavily relies on Swords Dance to break through opposing teams. Therefore, Haze users such as Toxapex and phazers such as Skarmory and Hippowdon greatly disrupt it.

Revenge Killers: Due to Mimikyu's below-average HP and defensive stats, it can easily be dealt with by faster revenge killers such as Urshifu, Zarude, and Mega Lopunny. However, Mimikyu can deal with said threats if Disguise is intact.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Celesteela and Mega Scizor are able to deal shrug off any hits from Mimikyu and revenge kill it with their strong Steel-type STAB moves, while Choice Scarf Excadrill outspeeds and OHKOes Mimikyu through Disguise thanks to Mold Breaker.

Status*: All status conditions severely cripple Mimikyu's effectiveness as a sweeper. Burn greatly weakens it, poison puts it on a timer, and paralysis makes it easier to revenge kill.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Ghost)
sets.description:
Mimikyu is an invaluable asset for Ghost teams thanks to its part-Fairy typing allowing it to act as a key wincon in the Dark, Fighting, and Dragon matchups, access to Swords Dance, and excellent coverage. Additionally, Disguise lets Mimikyu act as a potent revenge killer as well, giving it an opportunity to handle extremely threatening foes such as Hydreigon, Weavile, and boosted Kommo-o while blanket checking most other Pokemon. Swords Dance boosts Mimikyu's underwhelming damage output to high levels, and it can be used on Pokemon that it forces out such as Mega Sableye, Tyranitar, and Mandibuzz. Drain Punch hits Steel-types like Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Magnezone super effectively while providing Mimikyu with passive recovery. Shadow Claw can be used instead to deal much more damage to walls like Galarian Corsola, Aegislash, and Slowbro. After a Swords Dance boost, Shadow Sneak OHKOes faster threats like Blacephalon, Gengar, and Alolan Raichu while KOing weakened foes such as Barraskewda, Tapu Koko, and Victini. However, be cautious of using Shadow Sneak against Victini if Psychic Terrain is up. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature is used to outspeed Pokemon like Kyurem, Nidoking, and Tapu Lele. Mimikyu should avoid switching into attacks in order to preserve Disguise. It is also best used as a late-game cleaner once walls are weakened.

All Ghost teams appreciate Mimikyu's ability to deal with Dark- and Dragon-types and act as a potent late-game wincon. Mega Sableye and Galarian Corsola both provide a defensive backbone for Mimikyu, switching into powerful attacks for it. Mega Sableye provides a useful neutrality to Ghost and Dark, absorbs Knock Off for Mimikyu, deals with threatening attackers like Blacephalon and Nidoking, and deflects troublesome entry hazards like Spikes and Toxic Spikes with Magic Bounce. Swords Dance Aegislash is a great teammate due to its ability to deal with or weaken walls like Galarian Weezing, Porygon2, and Celesteela for Mimikyu. SubToxic Aegislash can also be used to wear down walls like Hippowdon and Porygon2 with Toxic, which Mimikyu appreciates. Choice Specs Gengar takes on physically defensive walls such as Toxapex, Galarian Weezing, and Skarmory, making it a useful teammate. Additionally, Gengar absorbs Toxic Spikes for Mimikyu. Choice Scarf Blacephalon can also take on walls like Galarian Weezing and Skarmory while revenge killing foes that pose a threat to Mimikyu like Choice Scarf Excadrill and Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan. While uncommon, Alolan Marowak provides a handy Electric immunity against foes like Tapu Koko and Regieleki, making it helpful.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fairy)
sets.description:
Mimikyu plays a pivotal role on Fairy teams thanks to its almost perfect coverage between its STAB moves and its unique ability in Disguise, which lets it revenge kill certain key offensive threats such as Azumarill, Victini, and Tapu Koko or freely setup Swords Dance and sweep through already weakened teams with ease. Swords Dance boosts Mimikyu's average Attack stat and, in conjunction with Disguise, allows it to act as a potent late-game wincon. Play Rough is Mimikyu's strongest attack and allows it to deal with dangerous Dragon-, Dark-, and Fighting-type threats such as Hydreigon, Greninja, and Terrakion. Shadow Claw allows Mimikyu to deal with opposing Ghost-types and Psychic-types such as Blacephalon, Gengar, Tapu Lele, and Victini. Shadow Sneak further enhances Mimikyu as a formidable late-game sweeper, being able to deal with weakened threats and OHKO threats like Gengar, Blacephalon, and Latios after a Swords Dance boost, making Mimikyu a key wincon in the Psychic- and Ghost-type matchups. Maximum Speed investment along with a Jolly nature allows Mimikyu to outspeed key threats in Tapu Lele, Nidoking and Excadrill. Life Orb helps ameliorate Mimikyu's subpar Attack stat while also ensuring Shadow Sneak does considerable damage.

Klefki pairs exceptionally well with Mimikyu, as it provides dual screens support, Spikes support, and a Poison-type immunity. Spikes helps weaken foes, allowing Mimikyu to sweep late-game without much trouble, while dual screens make Mimikyu an even more reliable setup sweeper. Klefki can also provide Thunder Wave support, crippling threats that outspeed Mimikyu like Mega Aerodactyl and Mega Lopunny. Mega Diancie helps greatly in the Fire-, Flying-, and Ice-type matchups while also providing Stealth Rock support to chip down foes. Mega Diancie's Magic Bounce also blocks entry hazards such as Spike and Toxic Spikes that could easily cripple Mimikyu. Tapu Koko teams up well with Mimikyu, mostly because it deals with walls such as Skarmory, Celesteela, and Toxapex that can deal with Mimikyu without much trouble while also helping greatly in the Flying- and Water-type matchups. Tapu Bulu is able to break through Mimikyu's walls such as Hippowdon and defensive Water-types such as Toxapex and Swampert. Tapu Lele has useful wallbreaking capabilities with Choice Specs, dealing with Mimikyu's defensive checks such as Toxapex, while also aiding in the Poison matchup. Belly Drum Azumarill pairs well with Mimikyu as a secondary sweeper, mainly helping in the Steel matchup, which Mimikyu struggles in greatly. Togekiss is able to break through defensive Grass-types like Mega Venusaur and Ferrothorn for Mimikyu.

Kommo-o.comments:
Other Options

Dragon

Kommo-o has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Dragon

Fairy-types: Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Tapu Koko, Mega Diancie, and Mimikyu all can take any of Kommo-o's attacks, block Kommonium Z, and take care of it with their STAB attacks.

Psychic-types: Psychic-types such as Mega Gallade, Alakazam, Alolan Raichu, and Mega Gardevoir all can outpace Kommo-o and take care of it with their STAB attacks. Bulkier Psychic-types like Hatterene and Slowking can tank many attacks from Kommo-o and use their super effective STAB moves to take care of it.

Faster Pokemon: Faster Pokemon such as Mega Altaria, Choice Scarf Greninja, and Latios can outpace and OHKO Kommo-o with super effective attacks.

Status: Kommo-o being paralyzed makes it unable to outpace key Pokemon like Hydregion even after setting up with Kommonium Z, while Toxic puts it on a timer for the rest of the game.

sets.name: Mixed Setup Sweeper (Dragon)
sets.description:
Kommo-o is one of the best setup sweepers on Dragon thanks to Kommonium Z allowing it to omni-boost with Clanging Scales, and its useful coverage moves allow it to threaten various types such as Steel, Dark, Normal, and Poison. Clanging Scales is needed to use Kommonium Z, and it is also useful to hit Pokemon behind a Substitute such as Zapdos and Suicune. Drain Punch allows Kommo-o to take care of troubling Normal-, Steel-, Ice-, and Dark-types such as Blissey, Heatran, Mamoswine, and Tyranitar while giving it some passive recovery. Flamethrower goes well with its Fighting typing, as it enables Kommo-o to take care of other Steel- and Ice-types such as Mega Scizor, Corviknight, and Avalugg. Taunt is used to avoid phazing from Whirlwind users like Skarmory and Hippowdon and Toxapex's Haze, along with blocking Toxic from Pokemon like Aegislash and Blissey. Clangorous Soul is an option over Taunt to boost Kommo-o's stats even further, but it makes Kommo-o prone to being phazed by Mantine and a healthy Skarmory and has a huge drawback of costing a third of its HP. Soundproof is used to make Ditto and opposing Kommo-o unable to revenge kill Kommo-o with Clanging Scales. A Naive nature with 252 Speed EVs allows it to outpace Pokemon like Mamoswine, speed tie with Nidoking, and outspeed Mega Lopunny and Zeraora after using Kommonium Z.

Garchomp is great to pair with Kommo-o, as it can set up Stealth Rock and take care of Pokemon like Jirachi for it. Kyurem is great to help beat Water-types that can hinder Kommo-o like Tapu Fini and Greninja with Freeze-Dry. Dragalge can provide Toxic Spikes to make it easier for Kommo-o to sweep in Normal- and Dark-type matchups and can use Flip Turn to safely bring in Kommo-o. Dragalge's Poison typing also allows it to come into special Fairy-type attacks from Tapu Koko and Tapu Fini and take care of them with Sludge Wave. Dragalge can also absorb Toxic Spikes to protect Kommo-o from being poisoned. Mega Altaria pairs well with Kommo-o, forming a Dark-type breaking core with Mega Altaria taking care of Mega Sableye and Mandibuzz while Kommo-o takes care of Bisharp. Latias is great speed control for Dragon teams, as it can take care of Keldeo, Mega Swampert, and Cloyster after it uses Shell Smash. It is also useful to get rid of entry hazards with Defog and bring back Kommo-o to full health with Healing Wish. Mega Latias is a great teammate for Kommo-o, as it can help greatly in the Flying-type matchup by taking care of Tornadus-T and Zapdos thanks to its BoltBeam coverage. Hydreigon helps greatly in the Psychic- and Ghost-type matchups taking care of threats like Blacephalon and Celebi. Hydreigon can also bring Kommo-o in with U-turn.

Tapu Koko.comments:
Other Options

Electric

Tapu Koko can opt for Expert Belt in lieu of Choice Specs to switch moves freely, further improving the Water- and Flying-type matchups. However, it generally appreciates the extra wallbreaking power provided by Choice Specs more, as it better deals with Dragon-type threats. Tapu Koko can also opt for a utility pivot set with Thunderbolt, Hidden Power Ice, U-turn, and Taunt along with Heavy Duty Boots. U-turn allows it to pivot out, even against Ground-types, and bring in its teammates, while Taunt helps against walls that rely on recovery such as Porygon2.

Fairy

Heavy-Duty Boots can be run over Magnet to make Tapu Koko less prone to being worn down by entry hazards, but it misses out on an extra boost to its Electric-type attacks. Grass Knot can be used over Taunt to hit Water-types such as Swampert and Gastrodon, but Tapu Koko would no longer be able to effectively shut down walls. Choice Specs allows Tapu Koko to become a fearsome wallbreaker, but it will be Choice-locked and the Flying matchup becomes tougher because the opponent can scout more easily. Shuca Berry is another option that eases Tapu Koko's ability to take on threatening Ground-types such as Gliscor and Landorus.

Checks and Counters

Electric

Ground-types: Ground-type Pokemon like Mamoswine, Seismitoad, and Gastrodon that shrug off most of Tapu Koko's attacks can switch in against it and KO it with their STAB move,s while faster Ground-types like Choice Scarf Landorus-T and Sand Rush Excadrill outspeed and OHKO Tapu Koko with Earthquake. However, Ground-types like Hippowdon and Seismitoad need to be wary of Grass Knot, while Landorus and Gliscor fall against Hidden Power Ice.

Grass-types: Defensive Grass-types like Mega Venusaur, Ferrothorn, and Cradily can comfortably switch in against any of Tapu Koko's attacks and lose little to no HP in the process. Mega Venusaur in particular can threaten to KO it with Sludge Bomb.

Special Walls: Specially defensive walls like Blissey and Alolan Muk can switch in against Tapu Koko, and Blissey can threaten to cripple it with status moves like Toxic, while Alolan Muk can threaten it with Poison Jab.

Revenge Killers: Faster threats like Choice Scarf Greninja, Choice Scarf Blacephalon, and Mega Aerodactyl that outspeed Tapu Koko threaten to revenge kill and OHKO it with their super effective coverage options after minor chip damage.

Fairy

Ground-types: Hippowdon, Excadrill, Gastrodon, and Swampert are examples of Ground-types that take very little damage from Hidden Power Ice and can OHKO Tapu Koko with Earthquake.

Electric-resistant Pokemon: Since Thunderbolt is Tapu Koko's main form of damage, it is forced out by anything that resists it.

Special Walls: Walls such as Blissey, Ferrothorn, and Tyranitar take little damage from Tapu Koko's strongest attacks, but they dislike being afflicted by Taunt.

Revenge Killers: Tapu Koko is prone to being revenge killed by fast foes like Mega Aerodactyl and Choice Scarf Greninja with their coverage moves such as Earthquake and Gunk Shot, respectively.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Electric)
sets.description:
An amazing ability in Electric Surge that sets up Electric Terrain, bolstering Electric-type attacks of both itself and its teammates, along with an above average Speed tier and a great secondary typing in Fairy makes Tapu Koko a primary threat on Electric-type teams. Thunderbolt is amplified thanks to Electric Terrain. Dazzling Gleam helps deal with troublesome Dragon-, Fighting-, and Dark-type Pokemon such as unboosted Mega Altaria, Mega Gallade, and Zarude. Hidden Power Ice deals with troublesome Ground-types like Landorus and Gliscor, which freely switch in against Electric-type attacks. Volt Switch allows Tapu Koko to act as a great offensive pivot to maintain offensive pressure while to bring teammates safely into the field. Grass Knot can be used to better deal with Ground-types like Hippowdon and Swampert, which otherwise freely switch in against Tapu Koko. 4 Defense EVs ensure Tapu Koko always survives an Earthquake from Gliscor at full HP. Maximum Special Attack investment along with Choice Specs makes Tapu Koko a reliable wallbreaker, while maximum Speed along with a Timid nature ensures it outspeeds Pokemon like Weavile and Cinderace.

Zapdos is a great teammate for Tapu Koko, as it provides a much needed Ground immunity and Defog support while also dealing with physical threats like Mega Scizor, Rillaboom, and Tapu Bulu. Defog helps Tapu Koko pivot freely, but Choice Specs Zapdos can also be a great teammate, as it comfortably deals with bulky Grass-types like Mega Venusaur and Cradily. Rotom-W provides a secondary Ground immunity with Levitate, can deal with Ground-types like Hippowdon and Mamoswine thanks to Hydro Pump, provides a switch-in against Fire- and Water-types like Choice Scarf Blacephalon and Mega Swampert, and cripples physical attackers like Mega Swampert thanks to Will-O-Wisp. Alolan Raichu easily benefits the most from Electric Terrain set up by Tapu Koko while also using it to revenge kill faster threats like Sand Rush Excadrill, Choice Scarf Greninja, and Mega Aerodactyl, which Tapu Koko fails to deal with. Alolan Raichu's Psychic can beat troublesome Poison-types like Mega Venusaur, while Focus Blast can get rid of troublesome walls like Ferrothorn, for Tapu Koko and Grass Knot can cover for Tapu Koko not running a move. Tapu Koko in return deals with troublesome Dark- and Dragon-types like Krookodile and Mega Latias. Zeraora is the best available physical attacker for Electric-type teams and can help greatly in the Normal-, Ghost-, and Dragon-type matchups thanks to Close Combat, Knock Off, and Play Rough, respectively, while also dealing with walls in Blissey and Ferrothorn that Tapu Koko falls short against. Choice Specs Regieleki pairs well as a monstrous wallbreaker with Rising Voltage when paired with Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain, being able to 2HKO major threats to Tapu Koko such as Mega Venusaur and Blissey and providing a secondary hazard control thanks to Rapid Spin. Magnezone is able to trap and deal with Steel-types that Tapu Koko fails to do anything significant against, such as Excadrill and Ferrothorn, and act as a reliable switch-in to Poison-type attacks directed at Tapu Koko. Similar to Magnezone, Alolan Golem is capable of trapping and dealing with the aforementioned troublesome Steel-types while also being able to provide Stealth Rock support.

sets.name: Pivot (Fairy)
sets.description:
Tapu Koko is the fastest Fairy-type available and is a great offensive pivot. Thunderbolt is Tapu Koko's most consistent special STAB attack and has a high damage output thanks to boosts from Electric Terrain and Magnet. Hidden Power Ice lets Tapu Koko hit Ground-types that would otherwise be problematic for Fairy teams, such as Landorus and Gliscor. U-turn gives Tapu Koko a way to pivot other teammates in reliably and generate momentum. Taunt is great utility to help Tapu Koko shut down walls such as Zapdos and Blissey, making it easier to bring in a teammate that handles them effectively. Maximum Special Attack and Speed investment allows Tapu Koko to hit as hard and pivot as fast as possible, and 4 Defense EVs let it survive an Earthquake from defensive Gliscor at full health.

Tapu Koko's role as a pivot is appreciated by all of its teammates. Klefki provides a much-needed Poison-type immunity and can be brought in safely to reliably set dual screens and entry hazards that can wear down foes for Tapu Koko to clean up late-game. Tapu Lele makes for a great teammate because it's a powerful wallbreaker that can power through specially defensive walls Tapu Koko struggles with, such as Swampert, with its STAB attacks. Tapu Bulu takes on most Ground-types that Tapu Koko struggles with, such as Hippowdon, Gastrodon, and Swampert. Azumarill provides valuable priority in Aqua Jet and is also a very strong setup sweeper with Belly Drum while being able to take on all of the Ground-types that Tapu Koko struggles with. Mega Diancie is another good teammate because it can keep entry hazards off of your side that would otherwise wear Tapu Koko down, and it synergizes well with Tapu Koko in the Flying and Fire matchups. Mimikyu is able to break through the Psychic and Ghost teams, and Togekiss helps break through bulky threatening Grass-types such as Mega Venusaur.

Buzzwole.comments:
Other Options

Bug

Buzzwole can opt to run Poison Jab to better deal with Pokemon on Fairy teams like Tapu Bulu, Azumarill, and Tapu Fini. However, its other coverage options prove to be more beneficial in most scenarios.

Checks and Counters

Bug

Physically Defensive Walls: Physically defensive walls like Skarmory and Celesteela comfortably switch into and damage or cripple Buzzwole.
